user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SelectMultiple_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SelectMultiple_Impl(OS_FdSet *ReadSet, OS_FdSet *WriteSet, int32 msecs)
{
    fd_set wr_set;
    fd_set rd_set;
    int    maxfd;
    int32  return_code;

    FD_ZERO(&rd_set);
    FD_ZERO(&wr_set);
    maxfd = -1;
    if (ReadSet != NULL)
    {
        return_code = OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl(&maxfd, &rd_set, ReadSet);
        if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            return return_code;
        }
    }
    if (WriteSet != NULL)
    {
        return_code = OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl(&maxfd, &wr_set, WriteSet);
        if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            return return_code;
        }
    }

    if (maxfd >= 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_DoSelect(maxfd, &rd_set, &wr_set, msecs);
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * This return code will be used if the set(s) were
         * both empty/NULL or otherwise did not contain valid filehandles.
         */
        return_code = OS_ERR_INVALID_ID;
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if (ReadSet != NULL)
        {
            OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl(&rd_set, ReadSet);
        }
        if (WriteSet != NULL)
        {
            OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl(&wr_set, WriteSet);
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: This function contains no direct calls to the <string.h> functions covered by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. The only code fragments that could potentially involve string.h routines (and thus need inspection for out-of-bounds accesses) are the listed macro/function calls — they may internally use functions like memset/memcpy/strlen/etc. All other fragments in the function are simple local variable declarations, integer comparisons/assignments, NULL checks, control flow (if/else/return) and do not invoke standard string handling functions, so they do not need to be investigated for Rule 21.17.
